fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a locally small category \mathcal {C}, if the Yoneda embedding \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} : \mathcal {C} \to \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) has a left adjoint \operatorname {?}, then we say teh category is total, or totally cocomplete. This is equivalent to requiring the colimit of \pi _F : \int F \to \mathcal {C} to exist for every presheaf F, which is the value of L(F). Notice that \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} being fully faithful implies the counit \operatorname {?}(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A)) \to A is an isomorphism.

The universal property of the colimit says \hom (\operatorname *{colim} \pi _F, X) \cong \lim _{(Y, p)} \hom (Y, X). Using the characterization of limits in \mathsf {Set}, an element in this set maps F(Y) to \hom (Y, X) for each Y naturally, which is exactly \hom (F, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)).
In a total category, we can freely compose waves with arrows or other waves associatively.

Let us use f, g, h etc. for arrows, and u, v, w for waves. The composition f \mathbin {\circ } w \mathbin {\circ } g and its associativity is given by functoriality of waves. We define the composition of two waves by w \mathbin {\circ } v = \bar {w} \mathbin {\circ } v = w \mathbin {\circ } \bar {v}, which we can verify are equal by a calculation. Then u \mathbin {\circ } v \mathbin {\circ } w = \bar {u} \mathbin {\circ } v \mathbin {\circ } \bar {w} is associative.

Given a total category \mathcal {C}, it is a totally distributive category, iff the wave functor \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} \dashv \operatorname {?} with an obvious counit \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} \mathbin {\circ } \operatorname {?} \to \textrm {Id}, and iff the natural transform \operatorname {?} \mathbin {\circ } \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} \to \textrm {Id} is invertible (the inverse will be the unit of the adjunction). In this case, the composition operator \int ^B \operatorname {wave}(B, C) \times \operatorname {wave}(A, B) \to \operatorname {wave}(A, C) of waves is invertible, up to sliding B around with arrows.
The category of small sets \mathsf {Set} is a total category, and so is \mathsf {Set}^\textrm {op}.

The first claim is a special case of . For the second claim, we use the limit characterization of cototality. Given a functor F : \mathsf {Set} \to \mathsf {Set}, we need to show the existence of \lim (\pi _F : \int F \to \mathsf {Set}). We claim that this is a subset of \mathcal {P}(F(\mathcal {P}(1))), i.e. we need to show that all the other components of an element in the limit are determined by the F(\mathcal {P}(1)) component. This is true because \mathcal {P}(1) is a cogenerator of \mathsf {Set}.

fr:title.text: Presheaf category over a small category is totally distributive

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Presheaf category over a small category is totally distributive

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A presheaf category over a small categroy \mathcal {C} is not only a total category, as proven in , but also a totally distributive category. This is because \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}^* has a left adjoint \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}_! a.k.a. the left Kan extension. We need to be careful because \mathsf {Psh}^2 (\mathcal {C}) is not locally small. The colimit formula for (pointwise) left Kan extensions is \operatorname {Lan}_{\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}} F(G) = \operatorname *{colim}_{p : \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X) \leftarrow G} F(X) where F, G \in \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) and X ranges over \mathcal {C}. (The reversal of arrow comes from the contravariance of presheaves.) This is still a small limit, so it is fine.

For the special case of \mathcal {C} = 1, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}^* : \mathsf {Psh}(\mathsf {Set}) \to \mathsf {Set} evaluates at 1. We get \operatorname {Lan}_{1} F(G) = \operatorname *{colim}_{1 \leftarrow G} F = F where F, G are sets. So the left adjoint is the constant functor functor \Delta , such that \Delta (X)(Y) = X.

For a total category \mathcal {C}, we can define a functor \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} : \mathcal {C} \to \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) that will serve as the double left adjoint of \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} iff the category is actually a totally distributive category. Since \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)(Y) = \hom (Y, X), we similarly define \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)(Y) = \operatorname {wave}(Y, X), and call the elements waves.

A wave w : Y \rightsquigarrow X is defined by a family of maps \hom (X, \operatorname {?} F) \to F(Y) natural in the presheaf F, where \operatorname {?} \dashv \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}. This is intuitively a categorification of the “way way below” relation Y \lll X in posets. If we take F = \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X), then we get an actual arrow \bar {w} : Y \to X. This defines a natural transform \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} \to \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}, or equivalently \operatorname {?} \mathbin {\circ } \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {ろ}\mkern {-2mu}} \to \textrm {Id}.

fr:title.text: Presheaf category over a small category is total

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Presheaf category over a small category is total

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a small category \mathcal {C}, the locally small category \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) is a total category. In fact, the left adjoint to \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} : \mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C}) \to \mathsf {Psh}^2(\mathcal {C}) is given by \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}^*, i.e. the map that sends the double presheaf R to the presheaf X \mapsto R(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)).

To see this, we compute \hom _{\mathsf {Psh}(\mathcal {C})}(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}^* R, F) to be the set of natural transforms that assign an arrow R(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)) \to F(X) for every object X. On the other hand, \hom _{\mathsf {Psh}^2(\mathcal {C})}(R, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} F) assigns an arrow R(G) \to \hom (G, F) for every presheaf G. The latter obviously have a map to the former, and we need to prove that any map in the former uniquely extends to the latter. G is a colimit of representables, so we can decompose \hom (G, F) into a limit of F(X). The naturality requirement then forces a unique value for each component.

In particular, if \mathcal {C} = 0, we get a left adjoint for the yoneda embedding \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} : \mathsf {Psh}(0) = 1 \to \mathsf {Psh}(1) = \mathsf {Set}. In this case \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} is essentially picking out the terminal object, and \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}^* is the unique functor. We can also take \mathcal {C} = 1, then \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} : \mathsf {Set} \to \mathsf {Psh}(\mathsf {Set}), and the left adjoint is F \mapsto F(1), evaluating the presheaf at the singleton set. It is also possible to calculate this directly via the colimit characterization of total cocompleteness.

fr:title.text: A total category is cocomplete and complete

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A total category is cocomplete and complete

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A total category is (small) cocomplete and complete. This shows totality is a strong form of cocompleteness, strong enough to behave like cocompleteness in posets, which also guarantees completeness.

Using the colimit characterization of totality, given a small diagram D : I \to \mathcal {C}, we can attempt to construct a presheaf F assigning F(X) the set of all objects in I mapped to X, and require that F(f) sends the object i \in I to j \in I if there is an arrow in the colimit diagram going from j to i that is mapped to f (multiple of the same arrow appearing in the colimit diagram doesn’t matter). But this leaves many functoriality requirements unsatisfied, so we freely add elements to F for them. This will create additional arrows in the corresponding colimit diagram that end at existing objects, so the colimit is still unaffected.

It is nice to have a more uniform description of this. If we have a single object A in the diagram, then the resulting presheaf will be exactly \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A). For a general diagram, we need a colimit to glue all the \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A)’s together, and it’s not hard to see the required colimit is exactly \operatorname *{colim} \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} \mathbin {\circ } D, where D is the diagram functor.

For completeness, we use the same technique in proving cocomplete posets are complete: we can define \sup U as \inf \{x \mid x \ge U\}. In the same spirit, given a diagram U : I \to \mathcal {C}, we consider a locally small category whose objects are (X, F) where X \in \mathcal {C} and F : \operatorname {const}(X) \to U, and the morphisms are obvious. This is equivalently the comma category \operatorname {const} \downarrow U. The limit is then the same as the colimit of the functor (X, F) \mapsto X. But this functor can be constructed as \pi _G : \int G \to \mathcal {C} for some presheaf G, namely G(Y) = \hom (\operatorname {const}(Y), U). Therefore the argument goes through despite involving large colimits.

fr:title.text: Adjoint functor theorem for total categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Adjoint functor theorem for total categories

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given any cocontinuous functor F from a total category \mathcal {C} to a locally small category \mathcal {D}, it has a right adjoint without additional assumptions.

The idea of the adjoint functor theorem is to construct the large colimit G(X) = \operatorname *{colim}_{FY \to X} Y. But this is exactly the kind of colimits mentioned in . We can construct the right adjoint by letting G(X) = \operatorname {?}(F^* \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(X)).
A total category is cartesian closed iff the left adjoint \operatorname {?} preserves binary products.

If the total category \mathcal {C} is cartesian closed, then \hom (F, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A^B)) = \hom (\operatorname {?}(F), A^B) = \hom (\operatorname {?}(F) \times B, A). On the other hand, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} preserves exponentials, and therefore \begin {aligned} \hom (F, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A^B)) &= \hom (F, \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A)^{\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(B)}) \\ &= \hom (F \times \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(B), \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A)) \\ &= \hom (\operatorname {?}(F \times \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(B)), A). \end {aligned} Hence we need the canonical map \operatorname {?}(F \times \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(B)) \to \operatorname {?}(F) \times \operatorname {?}(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(B)) \to \operatorname {?}(F) \times B to be an isomorphism. But the counit \operatorname {?}(\mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(B)) \to B is already an isomorphism since \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} is a fully faithful right adjoint. Therefore this happens iff \operatorname {?}(F \times G) \to \operatorname {?}(F) \times \operatorname {?}(G) is an isomorphism for all representable presheaves G. Now presheaves are (large) colimits of representables, and being left adjoints, both \operatorname {?} and binary products preserve all colimits whatsoever. So we can extend this to all presheaves G.

On the other hand, if \operatorname {?} preserves binary products, then (A \times -) must be cocontinuous: Every small colimit diagram D : I \to \mathcal {C} can be equivalently represented as a presheaf F = \operatorname *{colim}_{i \in I} \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} D(i) with colimit \operatorname {?}(F). The presheaf for the product diagram A \times D(i) is \operatorname *{colim}_{i \in I} \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A \times D(i)), which is equivalent to F \times \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A), since \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}} preserves product and product is cocontinuous in presheaves. (A naive way to construct the presheaf for the product diagram is F \mathbin {\circ } (A \times -), but this doesn’t quite work because of contravariance.) We have \operatorname {?}(F \times \mathop {\mkern {-2mu}\text {よ}\mkern {-2mu}}(A)) = \operatorname {?}(F) \times A, showing cocontinuity. Therefore by the adjoint functor theorem for total categories, we know exponentials must exist.

Given a total category, if the left adjoint \operatorname {?} has a further left adjoint, then it preserves all limits. Since \operatorname {?} is a kind of colimit operator, this condition is a strong version of complete distributivity. Therefore we call the category totally distributive.
